column1: Yuba City is a city in Northern California and the county seat of Sutter County
Yuba City is the principal city of the Yuba City Metropolitan Statistical Area which encompasses all of Sutter County and Yuba County. The metro area's population is 164
column2: 138. It is the 21st largest metropolitan area in California ranked behind Redding and Chico. Its metropolitan statistical area is part of the Greater Sacramento CSA.

column1: The Maidu people were settled in the region when they were first encountered by Spanish and Mexican scouting expeditions in the early 18th century. One version of the origin of the name "Yuba" is that during one of these expeditions
column2: wild grapes were seen growing by a river
column4: a variant spelling of the Spanish word uva (grape).

column1: The Mexican government granted a large expanse of land
column2: which included the area in which Yuba City is situated
column3: to John Sutter—the same John Sutter upon whose land gold was subsequently discovered in 1848. He sold part of this tract to some enterprising men who wished to establish a town near the confluence of the Yuba River and the Feather River
column5: with an eye to developing a commercial center catering to the thousands of gold miners headed upstream to the gold fields. At the same time
column6: another town was developing on the eastern bank of the Feather River
column7: the beginnings of what later would become Marysville.

column2: Yuba City was a steamboat landing
column6: and approximately 20 dwelling homes with a population of about 150.

column1: Yuba City was chosen as county seat for Sutter County in 1854. The same year
column3: voters decided that Nicolaus would be a better location
column4: and the county seat was moved there. County voters returned to their first choice of Yuba City two years later
column6: and it has remained the county seat since.Yuba City saw its first major influx of population after World War II
column7: pushing residential areas west and south from the city's original center. Orchards were turned into residential areas as new homes were built for people migrating to the city.

column2: a series of storms dropped torrential rain throughout northern California. The deluge caused all the rivers in the region to overflow their banks and to break through levees. The Christmas Eve levee break at Yuba City was particularly disastrous
column4: and heavy damage occurring in the downtown section. According to Dick Brandt
column5: manager of the Yuba County airport in 1955
column6: between 550 and 600 Sutter County residents were rescued from the floodwater by helicopter.

column3: a Boeing B-52 Stratofortress carrying nuclear weapons
column4: flying near Yuba City encountered a pressurization problem
column5: and had to drop to a lower altitude. Because of this
column6: more fuel than expected was used
column7: and the aircraft ran out of fuel. It crashed before meeting with a tanker aircraft. The pilot gave the bailout command
column13: while avoiding a populated area. The aircraft was destroyed. The weapons
column14: two Mark 39 (3.8 megatons each) thermonuclear bombs (identified from declassified Department of Energy films and photographs) were destroyed on impact though no explosion took place
column15: and there was no release of radioactive material as a result.

column3: a school bus carrying members of the Yuba City High School's choir to a performance at Miramonte High School in Orinda
column4: California plunged 28 feet off the exit ramp on I-680 at Marina Vista Road in Martinez
column5: California.  Twenty-seven students and one adult chaperone died and twenty-three students were seriously injured.

column3: five young men from Yuba City
column9: disappeared under mysterious circumstances. They went to a basketball game in Chico and on their way back drove up to a mountain road away from the main road back to Yuba
column10: where their car had been found later

column1: Four of the men were later found in and near a trailer on June 4 of the same year. Ted Weiher was found inside the trailer
column3: covered in blankets. Inside the trailer there was enough food to supply all five men for about a year
column4: and enough paper and wood to light a fire
column5: but nothing was used this way. The corpses and bones of three of the other men were found outside the trailer
column6: but Gary Mathias was never found.

column1: Yuba City has been home to a significant Muslim population
column2: including Pakistani Americans descended from c. 1902 immigrants.  In 1994 the Muslim community completed a mosque that cost an estimated $1.8 million and many hours of donated work. Soon after
column3: the mosque was destroyed by an act of arson
column4: the first time that a mosque was destroyed in the United States.  Eventually the mosque was rebuilt with help of Sikhs
column7: and other groups.  The story is told in the 2012 documentary An American Mosque.

column3: −121.626201).According to the United States Census Bureau

column6: 14.6 square miles (38 km2) of it is land and 0.1 square miles (0.26 km2) of it is water. The total area is 0.53% water.

column1: The Yuba City area is located 40 miles north of Sacramento and situated in the Sacramento Valley. It is home to the Sutter Buttes
column2: the smallest mountain range in the world. The Feather River borders the city to the east and the area is sometimes referred to as the "Feather River Valley"
column3: which divides the city from its neighbor Marysville.

column1: Yuba City has a hot-summer mediterranean climate (Csa according to the Köppen climate classification system) which consists of cool
column4: January is the coolest and wettest month
column5: and July is the hottest and driest. During the wet season from mid-October to mid-April
column6: Yuba City sees frequent rain and is usually under the tule fog. Snow is rare in the valley
column7: but cold waves from the north may bring some light snow and ice. Spring is wet in the beginning but becomes drier and warmer as summer months approach. May has some rain
column9: not winter storms. Rain is rare from June to September. The Delta Breeze
column10: which comes from the Bay Area on summer nights
column11: helps cool temperatures and adds humidity. At times the Delta Breeze is strong enough to bring coastal fog inland to the Sacramento Valley. Autumn starts out warm but becomes cooler
column13: and foggier as the season progresses.

column1: Bus service in Yuba City is provided by Yuba Sutter Transit.
The city is served by two highways. California State Route 20 is the major east–west route
column2: running to Marysville to the east
column3: and Williams to the west. California State Route 99 travels south toward Sacramento

column1: Yuba City is home to the largest dried fruit processing plant in the world
column2: Sunsweet Growers Incorporated.  In 1988 Yuba City was home to the California Prune Festival. In 2001 the name was changed to the California Dried Plum Festival and in early 2003 directors announced the end of the festival's 15-year run in the Yuba-Sutter area. column1: Yuba City is known for its sizeable Sikh community. The Sikh population in the Yuba-Sutter Area has grown to be one of the largest in the United States and one of the largest Sikh populations outside of the Punjab state of India. Each year on the first Sunday of November
column5: the United Kingdom and throughout the world attend the Sikh parade in Yuba City
column6: which commemorates the receipt by Sikhs of their Holy scripture
column8: in 1708. The 4.5-mile-long parade features floats and a procession of parade participants. The 2005 parade drew an estimated 56
column9: 000 people while the 2007 parade was estimated to draw between 75
column11: 000 people of both Sikh and non-Sikh background. In 2008
column13: 000 people came out for the event which is now considered one of the largest gatherings in Northern California. In 2012
column14: the parade participants rose to an estimated number of 150

column1: Public schools are part of the Yuba City Unified School District. The three high schools in the district are Yuba City High School
column3: and Albert Powell Continuation High School. Faith Christian High School and Adventist Christian School (http://www.acselementary.org) are private christian schools located in Yuba City.  The Yuba City Charter School is K-12. Twin Rivers Charter is a K-8. St. Isidore Catholic School is a PK-8 parochial school under the auspices of St. Isidore Catholic Church.

column1: Yuba City is in the Yuba Community College District and is served by Yuba Community College in neighboring Marysville.
The main newspaper for Yuba City area is the Appeal-Democrat. The newspaper is printed in Marysville
column2: but serves the entire Yuba-Sutter area. The Sacramento Bee is also widely sold and read in Yuba City.
